title: Lodestone
text:
A lodestone is a naturally <a href="magnetization">magnetized</a> piece of the mineral <a href="magnetite">magnetite</a>. They are naturally occurring <a href="magnet">magnet</a>s, which can attract <a href="iron">iron</a>. The property of <a href="magnetism">magnetism</a> was first discovered in <a href="Ancient%20history">antiquity</a> through lodestones. Pieces of lodestone, suspended so they could turn, were the first <a href="magnetic%20compass">magnetic compass</a>es, and their importance to early <a href="navigation">navigation</a> is indicated by the name "lodestone", which in <a href="Middle%20English">Middle English</a> means "course stone" or "leading stone", 
from the now-obsolete meaning of "<a href="%3Awikt%3Alode">lode</a>" as "journey, way".
Lodestone is one of only a very few minerals that is found naturally magnetized. Magnetite is black or brownish-black, with a metallic <a href="lustre%20%28mineralogy%29">luster</a>, a <a href="Mohs%20scale%20of%20mineral%20hardness">Mohs hardness</a> of 5.5–6.5 and a black <a href="streak%20%28mineralogy%29">streak</a>.
Origin.
The process by which lodestone is created has long been an open question in geology. Only a small amount of the magnetite on the Earth is found magnetized as lodestone. Ordinary magnetite is attracted to a <a href="magnetic%20field">magnetic field</a> like iron and steel is, but does not tend to become magnetized itself; it has too low a <a href="magnetic%20coercivity">magnetic coercivity</a> (resistance to demagnetization) to stay magnetized for long. Microscopic examination of lodestones has found them to be made of magnetite (Fe3O4) with <a href="inclusion%20%28mineral%29">inclusion</a>s of <a href="maghemite">maghemite</a> (cubic Fe2O3), often with impurity metal <a href="ion">ion</a>s of <a href="titanium">titanium</a>, <a href="aluminium">aluminium</a>, and <a href="manganese">manganese</a>. This inhomogeneous crystalline structure gives this variety of magnetite sufficient <a href="coercivity">coercivity</a> to remain magnetized and thus be a <a href="permanent%20magnet">permanent magnet</a>.
The other question is how lodestones get <a href="magnetize">magnetize</a>d. The <a href="Earth%27s%20magnetic%20field">Earth's magnetic field</a> at 0.5 <a href="gauss%20%28unit%29">gauss</a> is too weak to magnetize a lodestone by itself. The leading theory is that lodestones are magnetized by the strong magnetic fields surrounding <a href="lightning">lightning</a> bolts. This is supported by the observation that they are mostly found near the surface of the Earth, rather than buried at great depth.
History.
One of the earliest known references to lodestone's magnetic properties was made by 6th century BC Greek philosopher <a href="Thales%20of%20Miletus">Thales of Miletus</a>, whom the ancient Greeks credited with discovering lodestone's attraction to iron and other lodestones. The name "<a href="magnet">magnet</a>" may come from lodestones found in <a href="Magnesia%20%28Asia%20Minor%29">Magnesia</a>, <a href="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>.
The earliest Chinese literary reference to magnetism occurs in the 4th-century BC "Book of the Devil Valley Master" ("<a href="Guiguzi">Guiguzi</a>").
In the chronicle "<a href="L%C3%BCshi%20Chunqiu">Lüshi Chunqiu</a>", from the 2nd century BC, it is explicitly stated that "the lodestone makes <a href="iron">iron</a> come or it attracts it." The earliest mention of a needle's attraction appears in a work composed between 20 and 100 AD, the "<a href="Lunheng">Lunheng</a>" ("Balanced Inquiries"): "A lodestone attracts a needle." In the 2nd century BC, Chinese geomancers were experimenting with the magnetic properties of lodestone to make a "south-pointing spoon" for divination. When it is placed on a smooth bronze plate, the spoon would invariably rotate to a north–south axis. While this has been shown to work, archaeologists have yet to discover an actual spoon made of magnetite in a Han tomb.
Based on his discovery of an <a href="Olmec">Olmec</a> artifact (a shaped and grooved magnetic bar) in North America, astronomer John Carlson suggests that lodestone may have been used by the Olmec more than a thousand years prior to the Chinese discovery. Carlson speculates that the Olmecs, for astrological or <a href="geomancy">geomantic</a> purposes, used similar artifacts as a directional device, or to orient their temples, the dwellings of the living, or the interments of the dead. Detailed analysis of the Olmec artifact revealed that the "bar" was composed of <a href="hematite">hematite</a> with <a href="titanium">titanium</a> lamellae of Fe2–xTixO3 that accounted for the anomalous <a href="remanent%20magnetism">remanent magnetism</a> of the artifact.
"A century of research has pushed back the first mention of the magnetic compass in Europe to <a href="Alexander%20Neckam">Alexander Neckam</a> about +1190, followed soon afterwards by Guyot de Provins in +1205 and Jacques de Vitry in +1269. All other European claims have been excluded by detailed study..."
Lodestones have frequently been displayed as valuable or prestigious objects. The <a href="Ashmolean%20Museum">Ashmolean Museum</a> in Oxford contains a lodestone adorned with a gilt coronet that was donated by <a href="Margaret%20Cavendish%2C%20Duchess%20of%20Newcastle-upon-Tyne">Mary Cavendish</a> in 1756, possibly to secure her husband's appointment as Chancellor of Oxford University. <a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a>'s signet ring reportedly contained a lodestone which was capable of lifting more than 200 times its own weight. And in 17th century London, the <a href="Royal%20Society">Royal Society</a> displayed a six-inch spherical lodestone (a "terrella" or 'little Earth'), which was used to illustrate the Earth's magnetic fields and the function of mariners' compasses. One contemporary writer, the satirist <a href="Ned%20Ward">Ned Ward</a>, noted how the "terrella" "made a paper of Steel Filings prick up themselves one upon the back of another, that they stood pointing like the Bristles of a "Hedge-Hog"; and gave such Life and Merriment to a Parcel of Needles, that they danc'd [...] as if the devil were in them."
